channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Clinton Emails on Benghazi, a Rare Glimpse at Her Concerns
item.description: Roughly 300 emails from Hillary Rodham Clinton’s private account were turned over to a House committee investigating the attack on the U.S. diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: Hillary Rodham Clinton testifying in January 2013 about Benghazi. She turned over roughly 300 emails from her private account to a House committee.

item.title: As Singapore Enters Mourning, World Leaders Praise Lee Kuan Yew
item.description: Tributes poured in from the United States, China, Britain, Malaysia and the United Nations on the day of the Singapore founder’s death.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A memorial outside of Singapore General Hospital on Monday after the death there of Lee Kuan Yew, the city-state’s founding father and first prime minister.

item.title: Russian Warns Denmark on Joining NATO Missile Defense
item.description: Danish ships would become targets of Russia’s nuclear arsenal, a Russian ambassador said, drawing an angry response.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Out of Yemen, U.S. Is Hobbled in Terror Fight
item.description: The evacuation of Special Operations advisers from Yemen is the latest blow to the Obama administration’s counterterrorism campaign, which is already struggling with significant setbacks in the region, officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Houthi rebel fighters have taken control of crucial installations in Taiz, Yemen’s third-largest city.

item.title: Out of Yemen, U.S. Is Hobbled in Terror Fight
item.description: The evacuation of Special Operations advisers from Yemen is the latest blow to the Obama administration’s counterterrorism campaign, which is already struggling with significant setbacks in the region, officials said Sunday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Houthi rebel fighters have taken control of crucial installations in Taiz, Yemen’s third-largest city.

item.title: In Greece, Syriza Struggles to Deliver Promises as Money Runs Out
item.description: Having promised an anti-austerity revolution, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is facing questions about whether he has a viable plan to restart growth.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Evangelos Venizelos, a defender of austerity in Greece’s previous government, called the Syriza party, which replaced it, “grossly unprepared and naïve.”

item.title: One Year Later, Ebola Outbreak Offers Lessons for Next Epidemic
item.description: While the disease has not been eliminated, aid groups take stock of what worked and didn’t, and continue to point fingers.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK and PAM BELLUCK
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Assessing the lessons of an Ebola outbreak that became the largest in history, with 10,000 dead.

item.title: Police Seek Third Gunman in Deadly Attack at Tunisian National Museum
item.description: Tunisia hunted for a third man suspected in last week’s deadly museum attack, as relatives of one gunman expressed shock at his involvement.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Yassine Abidi was identified as one of two gunmen killed during a rampage at a Tunis museum in which 20 tourists were killed.

item.title: Right-Wing Groups Find a Haven, for a Day, in Russia
item.description: Russia invited representatives of fringe right-wing political groups to a conference in St. Petersburg, where the activists inveighed against Western values and governments.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Representatives of fringe political organizations gathered Sunday in St. Petersburg, Russia.

item.title: Netanyahu Aides Cite Iran as Source of U.S. Tensions
item.description: As Israel’s president called for reconciliation after a rancorous election campaign, loyalists to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu blamed Israel’s opposition to a nuclear accord with Iran for tensions with Washington.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Richard III, Previous Visit a Bust, Is Warmly Received 530 Years Later
item.description: Officials said that the crowds in Leicester, England, were heavier for the procession of King Richard III’s remains on Sunday than they were in 2012, when Queen Elizabeth II visited the city.
item.dc:creator: JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: The remains of King Richard III, lost for more than 500 years, are carried in procession on Sunday for a later reburial at Leicester Cathedral.

item.title: Shy of Majority, Socialists Win in Spain’s Andalusia
item.description: They fell short of gaining a majority in a fragmented regional Parliament in which two upstart parties will have a combined quarter of the seats, according to preliminary results.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Susana Díaz, the leader of the Socialists in Andalusia, in Seville on Sunday after the party won regional parliamentary elections.

item.title: China National Chemical Unit Nears Deal for Tire Maker Pirelli
item.description: The China National Chemical Corporation unit will buy a 26.2 percent stake held by Camfin, Pirelli’s largest shareholder, and make a takeover bid for the Italian tire maker.
item.dc:creator: CHAD BRAY

item.title: France’s Conservative Parties Show Strength in Local Elections
item.description: Exit polls and early returns in the first round of voting indicated dissatisfaction with the Socialist Party of President François Hollande.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Afghanistan and Pakistan: The False Promise of Rapprochement
item.description: Afghanistan’s former interior minister and ambassador to Pakistan argues that President Ashraf Ghani should not gamble political capital on a miraculous U-turn from Islamabad.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED UMER DAUDZAI

item.title: Medical Students From Britain Are Sought in Syria
item.description: A Turkish politician who met with the families told The Observer that he believed the six students and three recent graduates were in a Syrian town under ISIS control.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Saudi Justice, Harsh but Able to Spare the Sword
item.description: A confessed murderer’s life was spared because of little-known checks in a judicial system regularly condemned by human rights groups for violating due process, lacking transparency and applying punishments like beheading.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Citigroup Says Court Order Will Let It Pay Argentine Bond Interest
item.description: The bank is among those caught in a dispute between Argentina and a group of hedge funds that hold the nation’s bonds.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Lee Kuan Yew, Founding Father and First Premier of Singapore, Dies at 91
item.description: As prime minister for 31 years, Mr. Lee transformed the tiny island outpost into a modern, affluent city-state admired for its efficiency and low level of corruption.
item.dc:creator: SETH MYDANS

item.title: Egyptian Official Says Protester, Shaimaa el-Sabbagh, Died in Shooting Because She Was Too Thin
item.description: The spokesman said Ms. Sabbagh, a poet and activist hit with a blast of birdshot from a police shotgun during a march to Tahrir Square in Cairo, would have lived if she had not been so slender.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Shaimaa el-Sabbagh being carried by another demonstrator after she was hit with birdshot fired by police officers.
